awd_titl_txt: US-Ignite: EAGER: GENI-Enabled In-Home, Personalized Health Monitoring and Coaching
awd_abstract_narration:
Prior work has shown that the unobtrusive, continuous monitoring of individuals with in-home sensors provides useful embedded health assessment, i.e., the continuous assessment of health changes based on each person's individual activity patterns and baseline health conditions, and can improve health outcomes.  Especially for older adults, identifying and assessing problems early provides a window of opportunity for interventions to alleviate problems before they become catastrophic and require hospital or nursing home care.

This project augments monitoring of individuals with a new interactive exercise coaching interface that will connect a remote physical therapist to senior clients in the home. GENI-enabled networking will be incorporated to support real-time interaction via high-definition video. The proposed project will meet the following objectives:
* Develop an integrated, interactive interface for displaying in-home gait history and coaching remote users on proper exercise form.
* Extend the integrated system to support GENI-slice overlay network channels.
* Deploy the integrated monitoring and coaching system in senior independent living homes

The project will impact technology, healthcare, policy, quality of life for seniors, and peace of mind for their families. The technology impacts include significant contributions to GENI-enabled networking and interactive interfaces for seniors. Results will further embedded health assessment and offer new ways to detect health problems before they become catastrophic. The project results will be disseminated both through traditional academic publications and by outreach to the general public via the US Ignite conferences and the university?s Engineering Week Open House in which hundreds of K-12 students tour the college.   Additionally, the project will recruit undergraduate students, especially women and under-represented groups.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
The project has allowed us to develop a prototype for achieving Physical Therapy-as-a-Service and to test the system in real-world conditions between a therapist located in Columbia, MO and older adults in homes in Kansas City, MO using the Google Fiber network. The prototype uses an inexpensive sensing platform that would facilitate widespread deployment. We conclude that this type of service is feasible but will require additional work to achieve pervasive use. There are key outcomes in the following areas:

1. Dynamic network performance assessment was successfully included in the project.  The results show that networking remains a challenge. Achieving high bandwidth, low latency networking required manual tuning. Addressing these challenges in establishing reliable high performance connections will open up tremendous opportunities in advancing networked services.

2. A quantitative evaluation of the depth sensing platform (the Microsoft Kinect) shows that, with additional processing of the depth data, it can be used to capture accurate measures of gait and balance, which can be used to aid in physical therapy and track fall risk. These measures have been evaluated against current gold standards: a force plate and a marker-based vicon system.

3. More development is needed on the user interface to allow widespread use.  There is opportunity to improve the user interaction experience on both the therapist and the home sides, and to incorporate gait and activity history from in-home sensors to help inform the physical therapy sessions.  Testing the service between Columbia, MO and the Kansas City homes showed that more work is especially needed for the consumers in the home to succesfully start and use the program independently.

4. The project provides an example of a successful interdisciplinary research project which includes faculty and students from electrical and computer engineering, computer science, and physical therapy. Students embedded in this type of interdisciplinary research team learn to work at the boundaries of disciplines and to communicate with others outside their own discipline.


Last Modified: 03/18/2016
Modified by: Marjorie Skubic

The prototype uses  an inexpensive sensing platform that would facilitate widespread  deployment. We conclude that this type of service is feasible but will  require additional work to achieve pervasive use. There are key outcomes  in the following areas:

1. Dynamic network performance assessment was successfully included in the project.  The results show that networking remains a challenge. Achieving high bandwidth, low  latency networking required manual tuning. Addressing these challenges  in establishing reliable high performance connections will open up  tremendous opportunities in advancing networked services.

2. A quantitative evaluation of the depth sensing platform (the  Microsoft Kinect) shows that, with additional processing of the depth  data, it can be used to capture accurate measures of gait and balance,  which can be used to aid in physical therapy and track fall risk. These  measures have been evaluated against current gold standards: a force  plate and a marker-based vicon system.

3. More development is needed on the user interface to allow widespread use.  There is opportunity to improve the user interaction experience on both  the therapist and the home sides, and to incorporate gait and activity  history from in-home sensors to help inform the physical therapy  sessions.  Testing the service between Columbia, MO and the Kansas  City homes showed that more work is especially needed for the consumers  in the home to succesfully start and use the program independently.

The project provides an example of a successful interdisciplinary research project which includes faculty and students from electrical and computer engineering, computer science, and physical therapy. Students embedded in this type of interdisciplinary research team learn to work at the boundaries of disciplines and to communicate with others outside their own discipline.
